body: @jkff I thought you might find this interesting because we finally have SDF support that is covered by SDF tests.
From what I can tell, Jenkins is failing for some reason unrelated to these changes. Let me know if this is not the case.
Wooo, thanks!!! I'll take a look soon. Meanwhile you can get some additional assurance that this works fine by trying a pipeline with TextIO.read().watchForNewFiles().
Jenkins: retest this please. (Backing channel 'beam8' is disconnected)
Rebasing to see if it helps with the Jenkins issue.
Does not look like this fixes the issue. Investigating...
LGTM. Thank you, I can merge after tests pass.

I think using `.gitignore` would be best. Note that the gradle build uses the Ant RAT task which doesn't look at `.gitignore` and still needs to have things listed twice, once for the Rat plugin configurtion and once inside `.gitignore`.
OK, at least some of the old failures were fixed. The gradle build now fails due what looks like a corrupt dependency file. The maven build fails due to unspecified "dependency problems".
@aaltay , Can you please have a look?
OK, I update the Maven RAT plugin configuration then. Thanks !

Thanks a lot for the review @amitsela I ended up doing how you liked, the start before the while loop because it was breaking the ValidatesRunner tests (on an initialization issue). Everything is cool now and the tests are green so I am going to merge.
I'm resuming the review on this one. Sorry for the delay.

@jbonofre just for reference this parameters allows to enable IT via docker (the emulator case). There will be a different PR by Alexey on mocking for the Unit tests (closest to your suggestion in the JIRA ticket).
ping? would be nice to get this in.
Fail seems due to a quota exceeded. Let me try again, else I will do a clean out.

Hey @chamikaramj. The initial issue was that schema was not set in BigQuery, but this is fixed afaik.
And currently tests are also failing due to quota issues.
However none of the above is related to this PR, this one is only allowing to specify timeout for mvn command that will invoke PerfKit.
I'm testing locally as Jenkins fails with Dataflow runner.
I updated `.gitignore` to use `**/*` syntax. Then, Maven `apache-rat-plugin` uses `.gitignore` plus some specific file we track but not distribute (as in gradle).

A downside to doing the direct pull request from `apache:master` to `apache:go-sdk` is that you get a moving target. If you made a temp branch like `herohde:integrate-upstream` to merge to `apache:go-sdk` then the test results would be up-to-date.
Henning, PTAL. Python postcommit failure is being looked at in https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/BEAM-3411.

I don't believe we should take this change in since the portability framework will decouple the data processing framework (Flink/Spark/...) from the users code since the users code will execute in a well known container allowing one to specifically know how the classloader is configured in all instances during execution so it will be under Beam's control during execution. During pipeline construction, the classpath should be under the users control.
 
I also believe that we should always use the TCCL, current class loader and then system classloader since its easy for users to reason about if we use it consistently throughout the entire codebase.

Thanks for the catch Igor! I'm thinking up a way to solve this, but also wanted to confirm a similar bug in the current code:

If you have a request with a range for all keys, and there are >= 4k SampleRowKeys, there will be over 4k splits.

example:
A table with 4k SampleRowKeys (yielding 4001 "sample buckets")
A request with a single range for all keys

Since there are 4001 sample buckets, splitBasedOnSamples() will currently output 4001 splits, one for each bucket. Is my thinking correct here? Additionally, is 4k a hard limit for splits, or is the difference between 4000 and 4100 splits relatively negligible?  Just looking to understand the scope of the issue =)

Yes, you are right, it doesn't appear that BigtableIO has the ability to merge splits across SampleRow key boundaries.

I'm not entirely sure what the actual hard limit on split count is, but I know there is some maximum split count that dataflow can't handle that I've hit in the past.

I'm not sure if this should be a blocker for this PR, just something that I noticed. 

I think a proper fix would be to split the work into 2 parts:
1. split the request into SampleRowKeys aligned chunks
2. split or merge the chunks to satisfy max splits and desiredBundleSizeBytes

I think part 1 should be handled by the Bigtable client and part 2 in BigtableIO
Thanks! Is there any way to add a test for this?

@jkff the existing tests will cover the new behavior (i.e. confirm that the exceptions are thrown properly). However, I'm not sure if there is a way to ensure the file is properly closed when an exception is thrown outside of Windows (we dont have the file handle in the tests). I have confirmed that the tests are passing on Windows though.
Also, this PR has 3 unrelated commits, could you exclude them please?
Can you clarify where the Bigtable client is in Beam? Are you referring to BigtableServiceImpl?

Portability framework doesnt really affects this java code so not sure. Also tccl is ok if the user uses a flat classpath base which is not my case which embraces javaee/servlet/osgi containers where the classloader can cross bounds depending the deployment. Beam leaks easily in such cases. Same applies to runner env since beam is embed.

Dont get me wrong, using the tccl to execute is good, to define proxy it is wrong. Only the classloader where the class is defined is valid, only this one due to java rules. Only reason beam passes is it doesnt support protected/private method proxying (yet?).

What about allowing the transform to define the classloader to use and default on the tccl? Does it sound better for you?

*[examples/java8/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/examples/complete/game/AggregatedTeamScore.java, line 166 at r1](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/apache/beam/4272#-L2N1lA4_DiJ5N2mWWUe:-L2N1lA4_DiJ5N2mWWUf:b-b6cm14) ([raw file](https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/d5eefb4a0d25fd520b9d799c3a54fbed6cbcb229/examples/java8/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/examples/complete/game/AggregatedTeamScore.java#L166)):*
> ```Java
>     }
> 
>     @StateId(TOTAL_SCORE)
> ```

Try some longer comments here to describe the state, like "A `ValueState` stores a single value per key and window. Because our state is globally windowed, it is just key partitioned, with one score per team. To store the value, the state must be encoded, so we provide a coder, in this case the `VarIntCoder`. You can also let Beam's coder inference try to provide a coder automatically by leaving it off, as it `StateSpecs.value()`." etc

Also cover the `StateId` annotation gives it an identifier, which we use to reference it in `@ProcessElement`

> ```

Two thoughts that might make this simpler to read in a tutorial: 1. You could store just the multiple that has been reached, so it is a counter. 2. You could use `>` to make it clear that it is increasing.

@chamikaramj thank you for your suggestions.  @jbonofre @iemejia could you also take a look? I also added io-it-suite-local profile that was missing and jenkins job definition.

>Writing using JDBCIO is fine. Probably your pipeline is slow since you do all the writing From a single worker. Consider creating a PCollection of seed objects (splits) followed by a Reshuffle() followed by writing.

I added only the reshuffle and it seems to be a little bit helpful. I didn't optimise it further due to a  problem: different "consolidatedHashes" get calculated for each test run for datasets bigger than 600 000 rows. This makes it unable to determine hash for a large scale dataset (eg. 40 000 000 rows). The amount of read and written rows is the same. I also have the same problems while running JdbcIOIT on larger datasets. Also, as I checked, the database content seems to be all right. I can create a JIRA for that after you review this PR and agree that this behavior is odd, ok?

600 000 is approx. 160 MB. I wouldn't call that a large scale test but I think it is something we can start with and then increase the scale and optimize it gradually if needed and if possible (e.g. after tackling the hash calculaction problem i described). What do you think?
Please create a JIRA and update the PR title to include that.
@jkff Thanks for the review, I'll get back to this once I'm back from traveling.
I think @tgroh will have some insight into this.

Chiming in late to this thread, but having spent way too much of my time fixing brittle tests due to strict exception messages others wrote, I would take a different balance here. The reason assertRaisesRegexp uses `re.search` (rather than, say, `re.match`) is that it's more helpful to see if certain valuable information occurs than check the message exactly. Also, these markers, along with escaping periods and such, add noise when writing (and reading) the test that IMHO outweighs the benefits obtained by stricter testing (the odds that we have  regression that only turns the period of a message into something else are vanishingly small). 

The value in these tests are that (1) an exception is raised for invalid configurations and (2) there is enough content to the raised exception for a user to act on.
I agree with you Robert, and I would add another value of message testing: asserting the type of exception raised, since a lot of these tests expect generic exceptions like RuntimeError or Exception.

One difficulty with asserting the type is that not all runners raise the
original (possibly remotely-originated) exception. This should be fixed of
course.

No it doesnt work - or the sleep is not enough for your machine. Do an infinite loop in a teardown and ensure your junit runner doesnt call system.exit - idea one does. Waituntilfinish will exit instead of waiting forever. It is just ignored in all cleanups.
